titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the David Benjamin Mixner Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday April 27, 2019 at 07:16

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of personal materials, correspondence, compiled family letters, clippings, subject and writing files, photographs, Vietnam protest memorabilia, and audiovisual materials that document David Mixner's life as a gay male, leader in the gay rights movement, author, and political consultant and advisor. There is also a manuscript of the Mixner family genealogy by Patricia Mixner Annison, David's sister; addenda/errata to the family genealogy; get well cards and photographs of David Mixner circa 1950s-1960s.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The papers are closed until January 1, 2031, unless researchers receive permission in writing to access them from the donor, the person holding power of attorney for the donor, or the executor of the estate of the donor. Researchers wishing to request access should email mssa.assist@yale.edu requesting specific box numbers in order to initiate the permission process, which may take several weeks.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by David Mixner for unpublished works he has authored or otherwise produced. After the lifetime of David Mixner but no later than January 1, 2031, copyright passes to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: David Benjamin Mixner Papers (MS 1862). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in six series and multiple additions: I. Personal, 1946-2005. II. Correspondence, 1968-2005. III. Subject Files, 1958-2005. IV. Writings, 1989-2003. V. Clippings, 1968-2005. VI. Audiovisual, 1924, 1964-2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: David Benjamin Mixner, well-known activist, consultant, and author, was born on August 16, 1946, in Bridgetown, New Jersey. He graduated from Woodstown High School and attended Arizona State University (1964-1967) and the University of Maryland (1967). He became a political activist as a young adult and participated in the civil rights movement, the movement against the Vietnam War, and the anti-nuclear movement. He worked for a number of Democratic presidential campaigns, including McGovern for President, Hart for President (national co-chair), Gephardt for President, and Clinton for President (senior campaign advisor). Throughout his adult life he has actively worked with, and provided leadership for gay rights organizations, including Access Now for Gay and Lesbian Equality (ANGLE), Municipal Elections Committee of Los Angeles (MECLA), the Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, and for organizations advocating for victims of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS). He is the author of Stranger Among Friends, an autobiography; editor of Brave Journeys: Profiles in Gay and Lesbian Courage; author of screenplays, including Dunes of Overveen and Fire in the Soul, and was executive producer of House on Fire, a film regarding AIDS in the African-American community. His consulting firm, DBM Associates, specializes in public policy, and works with individuals, businesses, and governments, in the United States and abroad, especially on projects related to AIDS and gay rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of personal materials, correspondence, compiled family letters, clippings, subject and writing files, photographs,Vietnam protest memorabilia, and audiovisual materials that document David Mixner's life as a gay male, leader in the gay rights movement, author, and political consultant and advisor. There is also a manuscript of the Mixner family genealogy by Patricia Mixner Annison, David's sister; addenda/errata to the family genealogy; get well cards and photographs of David Mixner circa 1950s-1960s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is arranged in two subgroups: topical and chronological. The donor has provided the following information about persons and events that are reflected in the chronological files (this information is not comprehensive):

list.item: 1994 to 1996. Battle over "Don't Ask, Don't Tell," the period when Mixner was on the "outs" with Clinton Administration, personal emails, ANGLE, the transition to hope with hope, the 1996 Presidential election.

1996. 1996 Presidential election, DOMA (Defense of Marriage Act), 1996 Congressional elections, fund raising for candidates, Victory Fund, my 50th birthday, ANGLE, Duane Raths estate, White House letters, Marcus letters.

1996 (September to December) - 1997 (January to February). Ken Starr investigations, "Stranger Among Friends," Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), presidential inauguration of Clinton, ANGLE, Victory Fund, White House emails, results of 1996 elections, roles of LGBT community in elections, personal, Marcus letters, Hamsher letters, personal.

1997 (January to June). "Stranger Among Friends," military policy on LGBT community, ANGLE, Victory Fund, Marcus letters, Hamsher letters, "Brave Journey," 1998 California Governor race, Greenville South Carolina Demonstration, personal, Digital Entertainment Network, White House emails Ken Starr investigation.

1997 (June to December\). Clinton/Ken Starr investigations, ANGLE, Victory Fund, HRC, Marcus letters, White House emails, Hamsher letters, political fund raising, the LGBT marriage issue, military letters.
1998 (January to June). 1998 congressional elections, the Clinton impeachment, ANGLE, White House emails, Victory Fund, personal, fund raising events for candidates.
1998 (July to October). 1998 congressional elections, ANGLE, Victory Fund, Matthew Shepard death and protests, Marcus emails, Hamsher emails, letters from elected officials.
1998 (November to December). 1998 congressional election results, White House correspondence, ANGLE, Victory Fund, Europe trip, personal, Leo Hindery emails, HIV/AIDS work.

1999 (January to May). Travel schedules, personal, to do lists, Jeff Marcus emails, Leo Hindery emails, 2000 presidential elections, 2000 congressional elections, assistance to Gay and Lesbian military members, NAACP AIDS project emails, White House emails.

1999 (May to September). 2000 presidential election, 2000 congressional elections, Leo Hindery emails, Jeff Marcus emails, Herb Hamsher emails, White House emails, DCCC Presidential Dinner in Los Angeles, ANGLE emails.
1999 (September to December). White House emails, NAACP AIDS Project emails, Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund emails, personal emails, 2000 Presidential campaign emails.

2000 (August to September). White House emails, 2000 elections, Los Angeles Democratic Convention, ANGLE, Mixner event at 2000 Convention, Victory Fund, congressional elections, Marcus letters, Hindery Letters, Hamsher Letters, personal.

2000 (July to December) -2001 (January). 2000 presidential and congressional elections, the contested presidential race, ANGLE, Victory Fund, Marcus letters, Hamsher emails, White House emails, Personal emails, Bush winning the election, Amsterdam trip.

2001 (February to May). Presidential Commission on HIV/AIDS, Jeff Marcus letters, TransAtlantic Partnership Against AIDS, International HIV efforts, Belfast Peace Conference, Out Fest MTV Award for "Dunes of Overveen", ANGLE, Victory Fund.
2001 (May to September). ANGLE, Jeff Marcus, Herb Hamsher, Victory Fund, Dunes of Overveen, Windows Media, fund raising for candidates, 9/11 in New York.
2001 September. 9/11 emails.

2001 (September to November).2000 presidential race, 9/11 event, ANGLE, Victory Fund, moving from California to Washington, DC, White House emails, fund raising events for political races, International HIV/ AIDS work, Empire State Pride Agenda.

2001 (November) - 2002 (March). Democratic Congressional Fund Presidential Dinner in Los Angeles, the 2002 congressional elections, the Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, Jeff Marcus letters and personal emails.

2002 (March to July). Congressional elections, Judith Light (and Herb Hamsher), Jeff Marcus letters, letters from Jeff Trandahl (Clerk of the House), personal emails and "Don't Ask, Don't' Tell" emails.
2002 (May to September). Bush peak years, the War in Iraq, and personal works.
2002 (July to October). Early John Kerry, Jeff Marcus emails, early Gephardt, Judith Light (and Herb Hamsher), Mark Shriver for Congress, Congressional elections, and personal.

2003 (January to April). Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, ANGLE, Jeff Marcus letters, "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" efforts, Gephardt for President, TransAtlantic Partnership Against AIDS (TPAA), letters from Amsterdam, and TPAA Conference in Moscow.
2003 (September to December). Everything from political, personal, organizational; beginning of the discussions around the presidential race, AIDS legislation, and personal emails.
2003 (December) - 2004 (April). Email, letters, and cards from Iraq, discussions of the 2002 Presidential elections, LGBT issues, and personal.
2004 (April to July). War in Iraq, the 2004 presidential elections, the Constitutional Amendment on Marriage, The Kennedy DSCC GLBT fund raiser in his home, Dave Koz letters, Judith Light letters.
2004 (August to December). 2004 presidential election, the Constitutional Amendment battle, congressional elections, and personal.

2005 (January to September). War in Iraq to Hurricane Katrina to political changes that takes place during this period. Includes letter from gay Americans serving in Iraq in different ways and personal letters.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.p: Copies of commercially produced audiovisual materials contained in this collection cannot be made for researcher use outside of the repository.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists two hard drives containing an interview with David Mixner. Topics in the interview include his childhood, politics in the 1960s, his coming out as a gay man, the AIDS epidemic, and equality legislation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The papers are closed until January 1, 2031, unless researchers receive permission in writing to access them from the donor, the person holding power of attorney for the donor, or the executor of the estate of the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The computer files are unprocessed and may contain sensitive information or be in a physical state that would prohibit use. Researchers wishing to request access should email mssa.assist@yale.edu . The request should outline the scope and purpose of the research project, why the researcher believes the material is relevant to their project, and contact information. If possible the request should also include a list of specific material of interest including collection, box, and folder numbers (or folder descriptions if folders are not numbered). The review may take several weeks.
